column9: 90% perfect, but the last 10% really bothers me
column10:
Most importantly, this is hands down the most intuitive and effective reading, note-taking, research, and writing tool I have ever tried. The method I have developed works exactly like I always wanted it with Margin Note 3 and offered more that I didn't even know I needed or wanted. 

I love that the notes highlighted link between the mindmap and the document, unlike notability, adobe, and Evernote. 
Organizing and editing notes are much more manageable, unlike my previous method of color-coding different sources and then cutting and pasting them into pages or google Docs. 
It's a significant improvement over Zotero for finding my citations again and quickly checking my page numbers. 
I appreciate the extensive storage for mind maps and documents--it makes it very convenient for referencing previous work or research. 
In addition, I like that I can export my notes to a document to continue my editing once I get organized and then export my paper back into MN3 to highlight and further rearrange my own words. 

However, there are a few things that make me crazy. In order of importance (to me):

1. I do not like the highlighter colors offered—at all. There are not enough to choose from, and they are the same lame colors offered at Walmart, which I never buy IRL because I find the colors distracting and ugly. 

I realize this may seem insignificant to some. Still, for those who connect deeply with colors and resonate with the process of color-coding for visual connections—this is an annoying limitation. I would love to select my highlighters from a color picker at best or, at a minimum, have another 20 colors to choose from with more muted tones and shades. 

2. The (+) sign for expanding the branches is minuscule (and translucent!)— even when I zoom in, it's difficult for me to see the sign to highlight it and open the branches. . That goes for the one in the upper right corner of the framework. The small circled one at the bottom of the trIt's a critical part of the UX, and I have no idea why you make it so difficult to see. 

3. The dashed line under the emphasis bubbles is too bold when highlighted to emphasize the document. In addition, I sometimes cannot read the text underneath because of all the bubbles around each word (why?) and because the dashes are so thick and obstructive. Why not eliminate the bubbles and have a finely dotted line instead?

4. When I go to the notes format and select only one branch to export to a document, it always exports allllllll of my notes, which means I have to go back and sometimes delete dozens of pages of notes from the document I imported them into. Does that make sense? I have this problem; even when I select focus mode for the branch and select only those notes then export--it still sends everything from the mindmap. 

Lastly, I have never once left a review for any purchase. The fact that I have taken the time to do this is a testament to how almost perfect this program is for me; therefore, it was worth noting these few suggestions for improvement. I have screenshots of my issues for further explanation if it is helpful.

This app makes several large tasks in my day much more efficient and intuitive. For studying, I use the combined mind mapping linked to source documents and also easy flashcard creation from within the app. For planning upcoming tasks/projects, the flexible mind maps help me organize and explore a potential workflow and put together a clear model that I can refer back to and edit very easily on the fly.

Excellent program. Yes, it is complex and the interface is sometimes unintuitive, but stick with it and you will be rewarded. The only way you will succeed is to use and keep using the program. What do I use this for? A knowledge resource for stewarding in a historic house. Each room is linked to other rooms and contains objects and paintings. Images on screen can hold text or links to long form documents. Each node can be hidden or displayed in a tree fashion with the main node and child nodes. As you find more data on a historic person, links to that data can be made.  You can go 'down the rabbit hole' as much as you please, adding more links. These links can be collapsed to keep the project from getting cluttered and yet expanded as required by clicking on 'action' symbols. 

Could it be improved?
Yes:
Allow custom label colours
Use contrasting document link '>' colours (black is difficult to see on a dark blue background)
Document links are visible in Tree branch style, but not in Framework branch style

In summary, a vital part of my workflow. You have to follow the path that it sets for you and that path is frequently not clear. More options would be helpful, but perseverance should save the day.

column9: Has potential, but not quite there at all
column10: On the surface Margin note appears to be the best option out there for making mind maps, taking notes, and excerpts from multiple sources such as PDFs and websites. However, once you get familiar with MarginNote, it’s limitations make it a disappointing, unintuitive and clunky experience making you constantly wish if only it was better. Margin note lacks fluidity and it’s not a true mind mapping software. It is more of an excerpt collection tool for making flash cards. Flash cards may be useful for rote memorisation but not everyone uses flash cards as there are better non linear methods of learning and organising notes. All maps and excerpts follow a linear tree structure which makes for a very rigid format to collect thoughts and make connections. It makes it very difficult for reading and reviewing notes because of linear hierarchy, inability to emphasise or give importance to certain nodes, and overall poor legibility with all nodes following a linear flow. The tree structures created by margin note are not optimal for reading and referencing back to notes or finding relevant information quickly. Legibility is reduced without being able to control the spacing, position or sizing of nodes. Arranging excerpts without making them child nodes or forcing them to become part of the rigid linear tree structure keeps them at risk of being automatically rearranged without their position being saved. No ability to make fluid arrangement’s or connections. No ability to align or distribute nodes. Once a child map node becomes part of a tree structure or group it can’t be resized. Once in focus mode of a child map, no button to unfocus, have to instead go back to the main mind map and reopen the child map again. That is a basic usability violation. There is no ability to go back and forth through history of child maps which were opened. Instead the only back button is to go back to the document browser which one rarely needs to do. Making links from inside one child map to another is a difficult multi step process. The browser used to add webpages is terrible. It lacks tabs, history or bookmarking. The workflow with the browser forces one to have to import one webpage at a time and once it’s added it can no longer be navigated. It’s just a plain document. To go to other links on the same website, one will have to go back to manage and import another page. This is a frustrating experience. The whole advantage of using a web search engine to study subjects while researching across multiple tabs becomes impossible to do. Websites should be able to be opened and navigated freely, with multiple tabs, without having to import them as documents one page at a time. The research tool is awkward, no way to directly search new topics, and one has to first select excerpts and research the whole text node. The research tool and web browser both can not search text within the page. Notes taken with a pencil are difficult to group and select. Pencil Notes and excerpt nodes can’t be selected at the same time. One has to first select the pencil notes separately and then bind them to a node. What if the pencil note is on top of an excerpt? Then you have to first move the excerpt and the select pencil notes. A very unintuitive and frustrating experience. Grouping nodes restructures and repositions all nodes and all positions are lost. Difficult creating child maps, Can’t convert text nodes into child maps. The pencil tool lacks smoothing options, lacks ability to make shapes, and feels very basic. Highlighting tool is terrible, it’s not highlighting the actual text/words, but drawing a stroke floating on top. If you move the excerpt the highlights don’t move with it. Ridiculous. The highlight tool also is only layering a colour on top which reduces legibility instead of using a blend mode. Syncing to iCloud or backing up feels clunky and syncing shows no status or progress indicator, so one is never certain if notes have been synced. Pasting or importing images from external sources is difficult and there is no ability to resize the images. Limited colour coding options. Can’t define custom colors. Limiting text writing and editing features. No support for different heading styles or presets. No cross platform support, makes you tied to the apple platform. Sadly the list goes on. Most of the time spent using margin note is spent working around its limitations. This review is intentionally critical because Margin note has the potential to be the best app in the market for its purpose, only to fall short because of poor implementation in some critical areas. In the areas marginnote does do well it is truelly brilliant. It seems there is little movement in trying to improve Margin note, and updates introducing improvements to such problems are non existent. Unfortunate.

The app seems to have a very small development team and features that have been indicated as being “worked on” for years on their forums are still not present. Toss in the fact that some great updates to the app exist as hacked together “extensions” by the developers instead of being baked in and you have an app that will amaze you up front, begin to frustrate you as you seriously use it, and eventually make you regret your decision as the lock in grows. 

With all that said, it’s likely the most feature rich option in the space. If the notes you’re making are something you intend to utilize the rest of your life…. Run. Run away now. This is a black box with seemingly no real intention of changing or improving anytime soon.

First of all, I can’t believe how content I was in paying for this product, and how actively I tell my friends about marginnote.  

Here are 3 things that would make it perfect for me.  

1. Addition of Markdown 
 - There’s an entire user segment of notetakers that are used to, and rely on .md format, and an entire notetaking app market that specializes in markdown. Markdown would instantly open marginnote’s innovative mindmapping concept to the technical .md-comfortable crowd. Programmers are also super friendly to markdown, and may consider MN3 if .md was available.  
Adjusting font styles using the keyboard UI is not efficient enough, so I don’t even bother using it.  

2. Mindmap Object Orientation 
 - The concept of mindmapping derives its value from the fact that it offers a visual-spatial element to the user, thus adding a new dimension to acquisition, and finally retention. I see the fact that ”child objects” can only orient to the right to be completely antithetical to mind-mapping. You must allow child-objects to orient upwards, downwards, to the left - this would let users experience the full psychological benefits of concept mapping.   

3. Export Options. 
 - The final selling point of MN3, for me, was that you allowed .pdf and .anki export options. Many products these days don’t pay attention to the fact that users don’t want to be constrained to one platform. It scares us. It gives us anxiety that our notes will be forever locked. This prevented me from using many other note apps. Although the preferred note format I’d like is .txt, so that it’s easily portable, I see how .txt can be difficult with the kinds of objects you work with. However, if you guys can make it possible, you may have a stronger argument for extending the lifetime value of your customers. (hint: maybe you guys can start with .md!)  

4. Feature Integration with .epub and Others. 
 - .pdf, .epub, etc., offer the ability to highlight text, add table of contents, bookmarks, etc. Is MN3 trying to be THE BEST e-reader? I don’t think so. It might be fair to acknowledge that users are doing reading elsewhere, highlighting on their kindle, or desktop, and then coming onto MN3 for more organization and notetaking. Therefore, developing stronger integration with basic text-based features would add lots more value.  

5. Related to #4^, MN3’s e-reader is lacking. The bookmark function doesn’t add value. The reading UX is lacking. It doesn’t seem like you guys have prioritized that much. It would be nice to see it get some more attention.  

Overall, I like this product a lot and would be happy to see it succeed. Please feel free to contact me and I’d be happy to provide any more feedback.

column9: Excellent program; Good amount of room for improvement
column10:
This app is really great, especially for students who learn better from reading notes or textbooks rather than lectures. I am really surprised by how the app is able to easily handle having many documents open and run a mind map on the side and still remain so responsive. I will say the initial learning hump or the program was definitely more than with most other note programs but I think it was worth it.

I would like to recommend some changes though, especially in terms of the apps flashcard capabilities. I would like to see some quick edit functionality which would be really helpful for when I realise I’ve really poorly structured the occlusions. Also being able to tweak the learning algorithm would be really cool, I currently don’t love that when I find something hard, the earliest repeat is 2h when I’m more accustomed to 5 minutes. Addition some more format options to the cards would also be really cool, such as hide all vs hide one options. And finally for flashcards, it would be better if for images we were able to set the resolution (for example, if it’s a very detailed and large diagram that can’t be broken up into smaller pieces, sometimes the text becomes illegible). Also, sometimes the occlusions can be a bit big, like if I write “inflammation of the choroid plexus (choroiditis)” and try to occlude the term choroiditis sometimes the occlusions will cover up the brackets as well, (especially the closing bracket), which can make some cards difficult to understand what I was asking myself for. 

For the note taking/text editing options I think there are also some small improvements that could be made. I think it would be nice if there were more cutting tools other than the square selected and lasso tool (ie something like a polygonal selection tool). And maybe a shape tool too. 

But these are all minor gripes when you realise all this program has to offer.

However, and this is a really big however, the app has been driving me crazy for the past few months. One of my main criteria for any app is its ability to work seamlessly across multiple devices and platforms. In theory MarginNote has this functionality. In reality not so much any more.

Partial syncing of content from one device to others, with each version showing a different stage along the markup process and never seeming to update. Constant spinning wheels telling me notebooks are being downloaded but they never do. Missing documents on some machines. Fetching data messages which when even left over night never disappear.

I need to use this app on multiple devices because of how I work, but it just feels as if it doesn’t currently have my back. I know, from visiting the forums that I am not alone, that this is an issue the developer recognises and plans to improve in a future update. Because I’ve raised my head and am looking to a certain competitor’s imminent move to MacOS.

MarginNote, I don’t want to leave you, but it’s not me, it’s you. You’re just making life too difficult for me right now. Please change. For both our sakes.

Hello, thank you for your valuable advice to marginote3!
For your suggestion: the reason why icloud is used is that synchronization is a function that requires very high technical indicators of the network disk, which is why there are few reliable cloud disks in China that can be used for synchronization. If the synchronization error is light, it cannot be accessed; if it is heavy, the data will be lost. Therefore, we have always been very cautious about the development of Compatible Synchronous cloud disk. Only when the reliability is ensured can it be pushed to the terminal. The SDK embedded in the Mac and IOS platforms can guarantee the reliability and compatibility of icloud synchronization. In the future, we will not forget to explore more synchronization solutions for users, but at present, we are still exploring more synchronization solutions It is recommended that icloud be used first for synchronization reliability (data security). The data is priceless.

column9: Good options but needs functional and UI fixes
column10:
I have been testing Margin Note to mark up assignments from university students. I see one major and a few minor issues.

* Margin Note flattens all of its annotations for exporting. Granted, it makes up for this serious failing by allowing the annotations to be exported in a separate OmniOutliner or mind map format. But, when one’s only goal is to markup and then review in a different app (e.g. DevonThink To Go), the loss of annotations is a failure. Also, Margin Note at least handles importing of annotations from PDFExpert properly.

* The sync with iCloud is inconsistent and remains unreliable. And iCloud is all we have.

* Importing only works at the root level, not in sub-folders.

* The fixed toolbar position at the top is cumbersome and restrictive (compared for example to PDFExpert with options for any side of the screen). The annotation menu seems to be sometimes here and sometimes there rather than being fixed in one place consistently. Finally, the choice of drawing colors seems to switch constantly depending on different cases rather than staying fixed at a set of favorites.

Overall, I am pleased with the options that Margin Note provides and the approach it takes. I especially like the options to tag notes. This allows me to use metrics such as #incorrect, #invalid, #sloppy, #improper, and others. I can then tally up the scores just by counting up and scoring using the tags. I have made only minimal use of the study mode and see no use behind using the research mode as yet.

The automatic outline and mind map created by the highlighting work just the way one would want them to work (a change in one is automatically a change in the other).  Of particular value is the ability to change the outline level (and correspondingly the mind map level) of a particular highlighted section so that the outline and mind map show appropriate indents.  The outline can then be exported to an outlining app or to Word (and other destinations). This makes it really easy to send comments on a document in a way that is user friendly for the recipient.  The upgrade makes all of this more intuitive and has a very pleasant UI.
